Privatizing USPS is a bad idea.Privatizing USPS is a bad idea.  The Post Office is the oldest federal agency in the U.S., and the only one explicitly authorized in the Constitution. It was specifically set up (main architect was Benjamin Franklin) to be self sufficient rather than make a profit and become an elitist mail service like European postal services at the time.  Post offices also provide jobs for our communities. Specifically in small rural towns where the Post Office may be quite literally the only employer.  And what happens to towns like Madrid, Ne that don‚Äôt have a carrier and folks go to the post office for their mail? Will they have to start paying for mail services? Undoubtedly those jobs would be cut with privatization as focus would shift from ensuring every American has equal access to the mail system to turning a profit for a private system of owners. Elitists don‚Äôt get to own our mail system.  #SaveUSPS

You see‚Ä¶in our conversation she casually mentioned to me that she gets ‚Äúabout a year‚Äù of paid maternity leave. That is a full year that she gets to spend with her baby, full time. To bond, experience all of the firsts, and maximize the health of both mother and baby for years to come. There are 195 countries in the world. 190 offer paid maternity leave after childbirth. 5 do not. These include Lesotho, Liberia, Papua New Guinea, Swaziland, and the United States of America.  Incredible isn‚Äôt it?  For a country that prides itself on ‚Äúfamily values,‚Äù the United States does a remarkably terrible job of supporting mothers and families at an incredibly vulnerable time when they need help the most. In this country, only 12% of women are granted any kind of paid leave by their employers. And horrifyingly, 1 in 4 women are financially forced to go back to work within just 2 weeks of delivery, before their baby can even support his/her head properly. American mothers are routinely forced to leave their babies long before either of them are physically or emotionally ready to be separated. It takes a woman approximately 40 weeks to grow a baby, during which time she experiences extreme fatigue, nausea, headaches, cramping, muscle soreness, heartburn, shortness of breath, varicose veins, and hemorrhoids ‚Äì just to name a few. And she gets through this all the while working full time, often at a physically demanding and exhausting job. And that does not even touch on the incredible physical act that is childbirth itself. Women need maternity leave to not only care for their babies, but also to recover. To recover from both the physiological and psychological aspects that accompany the postpartum period, which include depression, lactation issues including mastitis, fatigue, and pain. Studies routinely show that parental leave can have a significant positive effect on the health of babies and mothers. In fact, paid parental leave can reduce infant mortality by as much as 10%. It also has been shown to increase the likelihood of infant doctor visits and vaccinations. And it increases the rate and duration of breastfeeding, which has a number of benefits for baby, including decreased rates of infection and SIDS, and lower risk for asthma and obesity later in life.  And there are benefits for mothers too. Paid maternity leave leads to lower rates of depression and improvement in overall mental health in the months and years that follow. But this is not just a moral and health-based argument. There are economic benefits to paid leave as well.  Researchers have routinely indicated that paid leave benefits women economically because they tend to go back to work and stay with the same employer, which means their wages grow at a faster rate afterward. Paid maternity leave is also associated with better job performance and retention among mothers, increased family incomes, and increased economic growth. These might be some of the reasons that literally every other industrialized country in the world offers working mothers paid maternity leave ‚Äì some offering more than a full year of paid leave.  It‚Äôs unfortunate to me that in this country, we look at women having children as a personal decision, which should only be made if one can handle the financial burden. Especially when 40% of all Americans are having a hard time earning enough to pay for rent, food, healthcare, and transportation costs, and 62% of Americans do not fall into the category of middle class. The ability to have a family, like so many things in this country, should not and must not be available only to the wealthy or those who have the means to do so.  Rather than an individual or personal decision, other countries view having children as a need to collectively grow the next generation, from which all individuals stand to benefit.  I‚Äôm one of the lucky ones. While I do not get any paid maternity leave, I do get 6 weeks partially paid short-term disability and have enough savings to get me through another 6 weeks. But really? Should we be in a situation, as the richest country in the world, where this is considered lucky? Should I be in routine conversations with working women who literally do not know how they are going to afford to take even 1-2 months off from work after the birth of their child? And should the United States of America continue to stay in the company of Lesotho, Liberia, Papua New Guinea, and Swaziland, as 190 other countries around the world do more to support their working mothers and families?  The answer has to be no. We must do better. Please sign the petition, which will be sent to current presidential candidates and congressmen: http://chng.it/KxB9HfMS

Happy Juneteenth!On Juneteenth (June 19) we celebrate the freedom of all enslaved Black people. Although the Emancipation Proclamation declared freedom for enslaved people on January 1863, Texas did not acknowledge it until June 19, 1865.  Celebrate Juneteenth by: 1. Continuing to work towards uplifting the communities that still feel the negative financial, educational, and emotional impact of slavery.  Sadly, Juneteenth is not a national holiday, but Texas did declare it an official state holiday in 1980, and 44 other states, as well as the District of Columbia, observe it. Late Thursday evening President Trump threatened to impose 5% tariffs across the board on Mexico if they don‚Äôt stop the flow of migrants to the US- tariffs larger than those imposed on China. These tariffs, if imposed, will ultimately be paid by US consumers and jeopardize North American supply chains. It also places strains on the US-Mexico-Canada agreement that the administration claims to prioritize.  This is just another example of Trump attempting to bully other countries rather than practice diplomacy.  With summer coming, migration rates are expected to drop as the weather makes the journey across South America too dangerous to attempt. Honestly, these tariff threats are most likely just a way for Trump to try and take credit for the lower migration rates while failing to actually DO anything that de-escalates the crisis at our Southern Border.  Let‚Äôs be clear, America can not bully its way to diplomacy. That just isn‚Äôt how diplomacy works. This administrations harsh and inhumane handling of the migrants fleeing their countries in search of asylum are nothing more than a failure of the administration to deal with the migrant exodus. So what is the answer?  First we must understand the problem. Why are thousands of folx fleeing their homelands in Central America in search of asylum from the US?  The short answer is poverty. They need to work and provide for their families- something every hard working American can understand. The more in-depth answer is a discussion that includes a large range of topics including gangs, violence, harmful US interventions, and climate change.  I‚Äôd like to focus for a minute on climate change and how it impacts crops in countries like El Salvador, Honduras, and Guatemala. In Nebraska we understand the importance of agriculture so we should be able to relate.  One of the reasons Central America is suffering is because they have seen a 2 degree rise in temperatures. If Nebraska saw that type of change, we couldn‚Äôt grow corn. Think of the impact that would have on us- on the US. For Central America it‚Äôs coffee. Farmers are struggling to grow coffee. This change in climate has made crops harder to grow and has brought on new diseases (for crops) and new pest problems- resulting in massive losses in already struggling countries.  Climate change must be addressed as a part of the solution to the migrant crisis.  Furthermore, we know increased poverty leads to increased violence regardless of what country you‚Äôre in. Many of these countries face extreme amounts of violence and their governments and local law enforcement are often corrupt or incapable of dealing with the violence. So people flee to the US in search of work and safety. As Warsan Shire states in the poem ‚ÄúHome‚Äù; ‚ÄúNo one leaves home unless home is the mouth of a shark‚Äù.   The migrant exodus is a cry for help. People are running from the mouth of a shark.  I have 3 children- 2 of which are preschool aged. I can‚Äôt imagine walking thousands of miles with no money, food, or resources unless there simply was not another choice. This is important to recognize as we discuss the crisis at our Southern Border. The demonization of these folks seeking asylum has been harmful- to them, and to us.  We knew the migrant caravans were coming. We had months to prepare. But rather than deal with this very real crisis, Trump and the GOP has used it to promote fear and implement inhumane policies. Rather than build up support and send resources to assist those seeking asylum from violence and poverty, Trump and the GOP sent soldiers and advocated to build a wall to keep them out. They‚Äôve used it to fill their pockets and seek re-election based on false pretenses.  This was our first mistake- failing to prepare adequately for what we KNEW was coming. This has resulted in some really inhumane practices including separating families and caging (and losing) children. Detention centers face extreme overcrowding placing immigrants and border patrol agents in unsafe situations. The POTUS‚Äôs rhetoric has encouraged armed militia to take it upon themselves to ‚Äúpatrol‚Äù the border, further contributing to the chaos and increasing risks to immigrants, US Citizens, and BPAs.  This administration‚Äôs immigration policies and the handling of the migrant exodus is inhumane and dangerous. We must take a humane and pro-active stance on immigration. Rather than sending troops, we should be sending social workers, healthcare professionals, and lawyers. We should be utilizing our resources in a way that helps quickly screen and process asylum seekers, rather than filling up detention centers and placing huge strains on our systems. text: Earlier today I was chatting with one of my best friends who lives in Finland. We are both pregnant with our first babies. It‚Äôs an exciting time and I‚Äôm so happy to be able to share in the experience with her. But in my conversation with her this morning, it became very clear that there is one thing that we will both experience very differently.  Maternity Leave.  You see‚Ä¶in our conversation she casually mentioned to me that she gets ‚Äúabout a year‚Äù of paid maternity leave. That is a full year that she gets to spend with her baby, full time. To bond, experience all of the firsts, and maximize the health of both mother and baby for years to come. There are 195 countries in the world. 190 offer paid maternity leave after childbirth. 5 do not. These include Lesotho, Liberia, Papua New Guinea, Swaziland, and the United States of America.  Incredible isn‚Äôt it?  For a country that prides itself on ‚Äúfamily values,‚Äù the United States does a remarkably terrible job of supporting mothers and families at an incredibly vulnerable time when they need help the most. In this country, only 12% of women are granted any kind of paid leave by their employers. And horrifyingly, 1 in 4 women are financially forced to go back to work within just 2 weeks of delivery, before their baby can even support his/her head properly. American mothers are routinely forced to leave their babies long before either of them are physically or emotionally ready to be separated. It takes a woman approximately 40 weeks to grow a baby, during which time she experiences extreme fatigue, nausea, headaches, cramping, muscle soreness, heartburn, shortness of breath, varicose veins, and hemorrhoids ‚Äì just to name a few. And she gets through this all the while working full time, often at a physically demanding and exhausting job. And that does not even touch on the incredible physical act that is childbirth itself. Women need maternity leave to not only care for their babies, but also to recover. To recover from both the physiological and psychological aspects that accompany the postpartum period, which include depression, lactation issues including mastitis, fatigue, and pain. Studies routinely show that parental leave can have a significant positive effect on the health of babies and mothers. In fact, paid parental leave can reduce infant mortality by as much as 10%. It also has been shown to increase the likelihood of infant doctor visits and vaccinations. And it increases the rate and duration of breastfeeding, which has a number of benefits for baby, including decreased rates of infection and SIDS, and lower risk for asthma and obesity later in life.  And there are benefits for mothers too. Paid maternity leave leads to lower rates of depression and improvement in overall mental health in the months and years that follow. But this is not just a moral and health-based argument. There are economic benefits to paid leave as well.  Researchers have routinely indicated that paid leave benefits women economically because they tend to go back to work and stay with the same employer, which means their wages grow at a faster rate afterward. Paid maternity leave is also associated with better job performance and retention among mothers, increased family incomes, and increased economic growth. These might be some of the reasons that literally every other industrialized country in the world offers working mothers paid maternity leave ‚Äì some offering more than a full year of paid leave.  It‚Äôs unfortunate to me that in this country, we look at women having children as a personal decision, which should only be made if one can handle the financial burden. Especially when 40% of all Americans are having a hard time earning enough to pay for rent, food, healthcare, and transportation costs, and 62% of Americans do not fall into the category of middle class. The ability to have a family, like so many things in this country, should not and must not be available only to the wealthy or those who have the means to do so.  Rather than an individual or personal decision, other countries view having children as a need to collectively grow the next generation, from which all individuals stand to benefit.  I‚Äôm one of the lucky ones. While I do not get any paid maternity leave, I do get 6 weeks partially paid short-term disability and have enough savings to get me through another 6 weeks. But really? Should we be in a situation, as the richest country in the world, where this is considered lucky? Should I be in routine conversations with working women who literally do not know how they are going to afford to take even 1-2 months off from work after the birth of their child? And should the United States of America continue to stay in the company of Lesotho, Liberia, Papua New Guinea, and Swaziland, as 190 other countries around the world do more to support their working mothers and families?  The answer has to be no. We must do better. Please sign the petition, which will be sent to current presidential candidates and congressmen: http://chng.it/KxB9HfMS

Late Thursday evening President Trump threatened to impose 5% tariffs across the board on Mexico if they don‚Äôt stop the flow of migrants to the US- tariffs larger than those imposed on China. These tariffs, if imposed, will ultimately be paid by US consumers and jeopardize North American supply chains. It also places strains on the US-Mexico-Canada agreement that the administration claims to prioritize.  This is just another example of Trump attempting to bully other countries rather than practice diplomacy.  With summer coming, migration rates are expected to drop as the weather makes the journey across South America too dangerous to attempt. Honestly, these tariff threats are most likely just a way for Trump to try and take credit for the lower migration rates while failing to actually DO anything that de-escalates the crisis at our Southern Border.  Let‚Äôs be clear, America can not bully its way to diplomacy. That just isn‚Äôt how diplomacy works. This administrations harsh and inhumane handling of the migrants fleeing their countries in search of asylum are nothing more than a failure of the administration to deal with the migrant exodus. So what is the answer?  First we must understand the problem. Why are thousands of folx fleeing their homelands in Central America in search of asylum from the US?  The short answer is poverty. They need to work and provide for their families- something every hard working American can understand. The more in-depth answer is a discussion that includes a large range of topics including gangs, violence, harmful US interventions, and climate change.  I‚Äôd like to focus for a minute on climate change and how it impacts crops in countries like El Salvador, Honduras, and Guatemala. In Nebraska we understand the importance of agriculture so we should be able to relate.  One of the reasons Central America is suffering is because they have seen a 2 degree rise in temperatures. If Nebraska saw that type of change, we couldn‚Äôt grow corn. Think of the impact that would have on us- on the US. For Central America it‚Äôs coffee. Farmers are struggling to grow coffee. This change in climate has made crops harder to grow and has brought on new diseases (for crops) and new pest problems- resulting in massive losses in already struggling countries.  Climate change must be addressed as a part of the solution to the migrant crisis.  Furthermore, we know increased poverty leads to increased violence regardless of what country you‚Äôre in. Many of these countries face extreme amounts of violence and their governments and local law enforcement are often corrupt or incapable of dealing with the violence. So people flee to the US in search of work and safety. As Warsan Shire states in the poem ‚ÄúHome‚Äù; ‚ÄúNo one leaves home unless home is the mouth of a shark‚Äù.   The migrant exodus is a cry for help. People are running from the mouth of a shark.  I have 3 children- 2 of which are preschool aged. I can‚Äôt imagine walking thousands of miles with no money, food, or resources unless there simply was not another choice. This is important to recognize as we discuss the crisis at our Southern Border. The demonization of these folks seeking asylum has been harmful- to them, and to us.  We knew the migrant caravans were coming. We had months to prepare. But rather than deal with this very real crisis, Trump and the GOP has used it to promote fear and implement inhumane policies. Rather than build up support and send resources to assist those seeking asylum from violence and poverty, Trump and the GOP sent soldiers and advocated to build a wall to keep them out. They‚Äôve used it to fill their pockets and seek re-election based on false pretenses.  This was our first mistake- failing to prepare adequately for what we KNEW was coming. This has resulted in some really inhumane practices including separating families and caging (and losing) children. Detention centers face extreme overcrowding placing immigrants and border patrol agents in unsafe situations. The POTUS‚Äôs rhetoric has encouraged armed militia to take it upon themselves to ‚Äúpatrol‚Äù the border, further contributing to the chaos and increasing risks to immigrants, US Citizens, and BPAs.  This administration‚Äôs immigration policies and the handling of the migrant exodus is inhumane and dangerous. We must take a humane and pro-active stance on immigration. Rather than sending troops, we should be sending social workers, healthcare professionals, and lawyers. We should be utilizing our resources in a way that helps quickly screen and process asylum seekers, rather than filling up detention centers and placing huge strains on our systems. We also must end the role for-profit prisons and detention centers play. No one should be profiting off the suffering of people. These detention centers are billion dollar industries and we can be sure that that profit is used to influence congress into inaction so this industry can continue to fill its pockets. Our money is better spent on helping fund the numerous church groups and nonprofits working to address the crisis in humane ways.  We also must work WITH Mexico and Central American countries to resolve this problem. Bullying will not help.  As Senator, I will work diligently to develop humane immigration reform. DACA recipients should receive citizenship, TPS recipients must remain protected, and diversity should be uplifted. History shows us the contributions of immigrants. We should be welcoming our neighbors with open arms- not fear. We are America- land of the free, home of the brave. It‚Äôs time we start acting like it.
